moves.1. Nf3 d6: The first white’s move prevents to black e5. If black wants to occupy e5 must first prepare the drive (it’s ok also d5 or c5
moves.2. g3 e5: Natural follow-up of the English game
moves.3. Bg2: The bishop on g2 exerts pressure on the squares e4 and d5
moves.3... f5: This is the third consecutive move of the black pawn. It 'a bit' risky and not advised to move a lot of pawns at the beginning, better is to try to develop the pieces. In this case it is not an error, in fact, the pawn f5 increases the weight at the center and attacks c4
moves.4. c4: white seeking control of the central squares d5 and in particular d5
moves.4... Nf6: a natural response to capture the white’s
moves.5. b4: ambitious move that seeks to put pressure on the side of the black queen
moves.5... e4: Be7 would have been better. Black has moved twice the same piece just to annoy the white Knight, freeing up the diagonal for the white Bishop
moves.6. Nd4 d5: is the fifth move of the black pawn. At this point he should have realized the risk and prefer to release the side of King
moves.7. cxd5 Nxd5: with … Qxd5 black allows to white the best variations
moves.8. b5: This advance makes difficult to move Kb8
moves.8... Nf4: Black tries to dub the white pawns
moves.9... Qxd4 10. Nc3: white contrasts the move on the Rook with a useful developing move
moves.10... Bc5: Black threatens mate in one move, but white can avoid it with gain of time
moves.11... Qc4: normally is not wise to play aggressive moves with the Queen  in the first stage of the game because, when she is opposed, is squeezed and causes loss of time
moves.12. Bb2: The Bishop occupies the weakened diagonal
moves.12... O-O 13. Rg1: the pressure on g7 becomes dangerous. The white, playing Bf1, he discovers the tower and wins time
moves.17... Kh8 18. Bf1: This attack, long awaited, is decisive. After Bc4, the two Bishops, are aimed at parallel diagonals and send the defenses of the black in panic
moves.19. Qxb2 Rxf6: in exchange for the queen, black has got two minor pieces and a pawn that could help him to keep playing. But you remember my note about the developmental delay of the pieces?
moves.20. Qxf6: the white look for the simplest solution to make a final with higher pieces quality
moves.20... gxf6 21. Bc4: now black has to give a piece
moves.21... Be6: after 21…. H6 22. Rg8+ Kh7 23. Rxc8, black, as well losing in quality, is nailed on the last line
moves.22. Bxe6 Na6: Black avoids the checkmate on g8, but his situation is hopeless
moves.24. Bxf5 Rd8 25. Rg4: (the white menace 26.Rh3, after  25…Rg8 26.Rxg8+ Kxg8 27.Rg1+ Kh8, the game is over) 1-0
